title: Microstructural Analysis of Popcorn Kernel and Pericarp
content: Popcorn is widely consumed as a healthy snack worldwide. In the US alone, consumption reached 315 million tons in the years 2018-2019, while in China, it amounted to approximately 276 million tons [1]. Popcorn is composed of starch (7%), proteins (1.4%), and lipids (1%). In addition to these components, popcorn also contains phenolic compounds and essential amino acids, which contribute to its nutritional value [2]. The pericarp, the layer of the popcorn kernel, likewise contains proteins, lipids, and phenolic compounds, and presents nanomechanical properties that affect the popping process [1, 3]. This study focuses on the application of microscopy techniques and image analysis to investigate the microstructure of both the kernel and pericarp of popcorn.
